snippet: Pedro Hernandez’s confession to murdering Etan Patz has details that seem to be at odds with what is known about that day 35 years ago, but, for now, the focus of the case is on whether Mr. Hernandez made a truly voluntary decision in waiving his...
abstract: Jim Dwyer About New York column notes presence of Pedro Hernandez in Manhattan court room, where he is being tried for 1979 murder of 6-year-old Etan Patz, is as threadbare as his earlier confession to crime and other details surrounding case; says details in case are both few and of questionable authenticity.
lead_paragraph: Pedro Hernandez’s confession to murdering Etan Patz has details that seem to be at odds with what is known about that day 35 years ago, but, for now, the focus of the case is on whether Mr. Hernandez made a truly voluntary decision in waiving his right to silence.

headline.print_headline: Testing the Weight of Threadbare Confessions
headline.main: In Patz Killing, Testing the Weight of Threadbare Confessions
